    <gmd:identificationInfo>
        <gmd:MD_DataIdentification id="DataIdentification">
            <gmd:citation>
                <gmd:CI_Citation>
                    <gmd:title>

                    </gmd:title>
                    <gmd:date>
                        <gmd:CI_Date>
                            <gmd:date>
                                <gco:DateTime>2021-09-16T19:00:08.798Z</gco:DateTime>
                            </gmd:date>
                            <gmd:dateType>

                    <gmd:date>
                        <gmd:CI_Date>
                            <gmd:date>

                            </gmd:date>
                            <gmd:dateType>

                            </gmd:dateType>
                        </gmd:CI_Date>
                    </gmd:date>
                    <gmd:identifier>
                        <gmd:MD_Identifier>
                            <gmd:authority>
                                <gmd:CI_Citation>
                                    <gmd:title>
                                        <gco:CharacterString>Pierre Clement. 2022-04-30. "Blue Mountain Birch Cove Lakes Water Quality Baseline data" (dataset). 2.0.0. DataStream. https://doi.org/10.25976/6aej-nr27.</gco:CharacterString>
                                    </gmd:title>
                                    <gmd:date gco:nilReason="inapplicable"/>
                                </gmd:CI_Citation>
                            </gmd:authority>
                            <gmd:code>
                              <gco:CharacterString>https://doi.org/10.25976/6aej-nr27</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:code>
                        </gmd:MD_Identifier>
                    </gmd:identifier>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Friends of the Blue Mountain-Birch Cove Lakes</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Pierre Clement</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>In April 2021, a team of volunteers conducted a water quality survey by canoe of 21 lakes within the conceptual boundary of the Blue Mountain Birch Cove Regional Urban Wilderness Park.  Variables measured included Secchi depth (a measure of turbidity), dissolved oxygen, conductivity, pH and total phosphorus.  Vertical profiles indicated that all lakes were well mixed from surface to bottom at the time of sampling.  Mean values of each variable were calculated for each lake.  Secchi depths ranged from 1.5 to 3.0 m, dissolved oxygen ranged from 80 to 100 %, conductivity ranged from 14 to 187 μS/cm, ph ranged from 3.61 to 6.12 and total phosphorus ranged from 4 to 9 μg/l.  The highest values for conductivity occurred in the lower part of the Kearney Run watershed and indicate the addition of road salt and other pollutants from surrounding development.  The lowest values for pH can most likely be attributed to widespread acid precipitation during the latter part of the twentieth century.  Overall, the water quality of the lakes appears excellent but continued monitoring is recommended, especially in the lakes in the lower part of the Kearney Run Watershed such as Susies, Quarry, Washmill and Kearney lakes which are currently the most affected by development.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

            <gmd:status>
                <gmd:MD_ProgressCode 
                codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode" 
                codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>
            </gmd:status>

            </gmd:descriptiveKeywords>

                    </gmd:useLimitation>
                    
                    
                </gmd:MD_LegalConstraints>
            </gmd:resourceConstraints>
            
            
            <gmd:language>
                <gco:CharacterString>eng</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:language> 
            
            
            <gmd:topicCategory>
                <gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>inlandWaters</gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>
            </gmd:topicCategory>
            
              
            <gmd:extent>
                <gmd:EX_Extent>
                    <gmd:geographicElement>
                        <gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                            <gmd:extentTypeCode>
                                <gco:Boolean>1</gco:Boolean>
                            </gmd:extentTypeCode>
                            <gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-63.81147</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-63.68249</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>44.65967</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                            <gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>44.72005</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>
                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>
                                    <gml:beginPosition>2021-04-08T10:01:00+00:00</gml:beginPosition>
                                    <gml:endPosition>2021-04-14T15:30:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>
                                </gml:TimePeriod>
                            </gmd:extent>
                        </gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                    </gmd:temporalElement>
                    <gmd:verticalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>
                        <gmd:minimumValue gco:nilReason="missing" />
                        <gmd:maximumValue gco:nilReason="missing" />
                            <gmd:verticalCRS gco:nilReason="missing"/>
                        </gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>
                    </gmd:verticalElement>
                </gmd:EX_Extent>
            </gmd:extent>

            
        </gmd:MD_DataIdentification>
    </gmd:identificationInfo>
    <gmd:metadataMaintenance>
        <gmd:MD_MaintenanceInformation>
            <gmd:maintenanceAndUpdateFrequency gco:nilReason="unknown"/>
            <gmd:maintenanceNote>
                <gco:CharacterString>This record was created from dataset metadata by DataStream

</gmi:MI_Metadata>

name: 10-25976-6aej-nr27
notes: In April 2021, a team of volunteers conducted a water quality survey by canoe of 21 lakes within the conceptual boundary of the Blue Mountain Birch Cove Regional Urban Wilderness Park.  Variables measured included Secchi depth (a measure of turbidity), dissolved oxygen, conductivity, pH and total phosphorus.  Vertical profiles indicated that all lakes were well mixed from surface to bottom at the time of sampling.  Mean values of each variable were calculated for each lake.  Secchi depths ranged from 1.5 to 3.0 m, dissolved oxygen ranged from 80 to 100 %, conductivity ranged from 14 to 187 μS/cm, ph ranged from 3.61 to 6.12 and total phosphorus ranged from 4 to 9 μg/l.  The highest values for conductivity occurred in the lower part of the Kearney Run watershed and indicate the addition of road salt and other pollutants from surrounding development.  The lowest values for pH can most likely be attributed to widespread acid precipitation during the latter part of the twentieth century.  Overall, the water quality of the lakes appears excellent but continued monitoring is recommended, especially in the lakes in the lower part of the Kearney Run Watershed such as Susies, Quarry, Washmill and Kearney lakes which are currently the most affected by development.

notes_translated.en: In April 2021, a team of volunteers conducted a water quality survey by canoe of 21 lakes within the conceptual boundary of the Blue Mountain Birch Cove Regional Urban Wilderness Park.  Variables measured included Secchi depth (a measure of turbidity), dissolved oxygen, conductivity, pH and total phosphorus.  Vertical profiles indicated that all lakes were well mixed from surface to bottom at the time of sampling.  Mean values of each variable were calculated for each lake.  Secchi depths ranged from 1.5 to 3.0 m, dissolved oxygen ranged from 80 to 100 %, conductivity ranged from 14 to 187 μS/cm, ph ranged from 3.61 to 6.12 and total phosphorus ranged from 4 to 9 μg/l.  The highest values for conductivity occurred in the lower part of the Kearney Run watershed and indicate the addition of road salt and other pollutants from surrounding development.  The lowest values for pH can most likely be attributed to widespread acid precipitation during the latter part of the twentieth century.  Overall, the water quality of the lakes appears excellent but continued monitoring is recommended, especially in the lakes in the lower part of the Kearney Run Watershed such as Susies, Quarry, Washmill and Kearney lakes which are currently the most affected by development.
notes_translated.fr: En avril 2021, une équipe de bénévoles a mené une étude de la qualité de l'eau en canot sur 21 lacs situés à l'intérieur des limites conceptuelles du parc naturel urbain régional de Blue Mountain Birch Cove. Les variables mesurées comprenaient la profondeur de Secchi (une mesure de la turbidité), l'oxygène dissous, la conductivité, le pH et le phosphore total. Les profils verticaux indiquaient que tous les lacs étaient bien mélangés de la surface au fond au moment de l'échantillonnage. Les valeurs moyennes de chaque variable ont été calculées pour chaque lac. Les profondeurs de Secchi variaient de 1,5 à 3 m, l'oxygène dissous de 80 à 100 %, la conductivité de 14 à 187 μS/cm, le pH de 3,61 à 6,12 et le phosphore total de 4 à 9 μg/l. Les valeurs de conductivité les plus élevées ont été enregistrées dans la partie inférieure du bassin versant de Kearney Run et indiquent l'ajout de sel de voirie et d'autres polluants provenant du développement environnant. Les valeurs les plus faibles du pH peuvent très probablement être attribuées aux précipitations acides généralisées au cours de la dernière partie du XXe siècle. Dans l'ensemble, la qualité de l'eau des lacs semble excellente, mais une surveillance continue est recommandée, en particulier dans les lacs de la partie inférieure du bassin versant de Kearney Run, tels que les lacs Susies, Quarry, Washmill et Kearney, qui sont actuellement les plus touchés par le développement.
